TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi sealed beforefieldinit KeyTime extends System.ValueType implements class System.IEquatable`1<valuetype System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeyTime>
Public Structure KeyTime Implements IEquatable(Of KeyTime)

Docs.summary: During the relative course of an animation, a instance specifies the precise timing when a particular key frame should take place.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Each key frame's specifies when that key frame ends. It does not specify how long the key time plays. The amount of time a key frame plays is determined by when the key frame ends, when the previous key frame ended, and the animation's duration. See [Key-Frame Animations Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/key-frame-animations-overview.md) for more information. A may be expressed in several different formats, including a numeric time value, as a percentage, or as one of the special sentinel values or . ## XAML Attribute Usage \<*object* *property*="[*days*.]*hours*:*minutes*:*seconds*[.*fractionalSeconds*]"/> -or- \<*object* *property*="[*days*.]*hours*:*minutes*"/> -or- \<*object* *property*="*pctValue*%"/> -or- \<*object* *property*=""/> -or- \<*object* *property*=""/> ## XAML Values *days* An integer value greater than or equal to 0 that specifies the number of days spanned by this . For more information, see the property. *hours* An integer value between 0 and 23 that specifies the number of hours spanned by this . For more information, see the property. *minutes* An integer value between 0 and 59 that specifies the number of minutes spanned by this . For more information, see the property. *seconds* A floating-point value between 0 and 59 that specifies the number of seconds spanned by this . For more information, see the property. *fractionalSeconds* An integer value consisting of 1 to 7 digits that specifies fractional seconds. For more information, see the property. *pctValue* A floating-point value between 0 and 100, inclusive, that specifies this as a percentage of the animation's total duration. This should be followed by the literal character `%`.For more information, see the property.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Shared ReadOnly Property Paced As KeyTime

Docs.summary: Gets the value which creates timing behavior resulting in an animation that interpolates at a constant rate.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When a key time is set to <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeyTime.Paced%2A>, available time is allocated according to the length of each of the key frames to determine the duration of each frame. This will provide the behavior that the "velocity" or pace of the animation will remain constant.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Percent As Double
public: property double Percent { double get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the time when the key frame ends expressed as a percentage of the total duration of the animation.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When a key time is expressed as a percentage, the key frame ending time is specified as a percentage of the duration of the key frame animation. For example, if a key frame animation has a duration of four seconds and 75% is given as the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeyTime> percentage for the key frame, the key frame will end after the 3rd second.

Docs.exception: If this instance is not of type .

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property TimeSpan As TimeSpan
public: property TimeSpan TimeSpan { TimeSpan get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the time when the key frame ends expressed as a time relative to the beginning of the animation.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When a key time is expressed as a time span, the key frame ending time is specified as a time relative to the beginning of the animation. For example, if the time span is set to "0:0:2", the key frame will end two seconds after the animation begins.

Docs.exception: If this instance is not of type .

MemberSignature.Value: Public Shared ReadOnly Property Uniform As KeyTime

Docs.summary: Gets the value which divides the allotted time of the animation evenly between key frames.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When a key time is set to <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeyTime.Uniform%2A>, the total allotted time of the animation is divided evenly between key frames. For example, if the key frame animation has a duration of four seconds and there are four key frames, each key frame will last for one second and begin immediately after the preceding one ends.
